Award.AwardTitle: NDR1: A Point of Convergence in Stress and Pathogen Signaling in Arabidopsis Thaliana.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Plants are constantly exposed to stress, yet they have evolved numerous mechanisms to respond, adapt, and thrive under some of the most hostile conditions. In most cases, the ability to adapt to stress, whether from the environment (abiotic) or predators (biotic), simply requires a "reallocation of resources". For example, under conditions of drought, plants down-regulate growth and development, both being energy-expensive processes, in favor of minimizing water loss. Similarly, when plants are infected by pathogens, the primary goal is to restrict pathogen access to nutrients. This project seeks to understand how plants utilize basic physiological processes to respond to stress. To do this, the project will investigate how biotic stress signaling is activated and regulated, and moreover, how this signaling process is interlinked with general host physiology and plant health. The principal investigator hypothesizes that in a manner similar to humans, plants utilize mechanisms to integrate environmental and pathogen-related stress signaling responses. The goal of this project is to understand how abiotic and biotic stress signaling is co-regulated, and to develop a model of how plants sense the world around them, process these perceived stimuli, and ultimately, survive under a variety of stress conditions. The impact of this work links basic plant health to environment, threats from pathogens, and in total, food security.

The project includes an extensive outreach component. In short, a teaching module will be conducted by graduate and post-doctoral researchers in principal investigator's lab and carried out in collaboration with the Michigan State University Children's Garden and 4H Outreach Program. The major focus will be to educate elementary school children on the relationship(s) between environment, plant health, food, and sustainability. The goal of this outreach is to increase the awareness and understanding of young people of how food, and ultimately human health, is impacted by the environment, and moreover, to illustrate how humans impact the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation award to Michigan State University asked the primary question: How do plants simultaneously respond to biotic (i.e., pathogen infection) and abiotic (i.e., drought) stress? In the current project, we were interested in defining the genetic basis, including the regulation, of how plants survive under harsh climate conditions. To do this, we reasoned that plants must first perceive the stress, then interpret the nature of the stress, and finally, activate the necessary response to ensure survival. In support of this, we obtained preliminary data demonstrating that one gene, NDR1 (non-race specific disease resistance-1), which was previously characterized by our laboratory and others, was required not only for resistance to pathogens, but also a plants response to limited water. With this, we hypothesized that as plants are infected with pathogens, they are subjected to challenges related to water and nutrient homeostasis; much in the same way that when humans are sick, we also require fluids to help our bodies recover from our illness, which is sometime related to a pathogen infection (i.e., the flu). Indeed, throughout the course of the funding period, we further found that many of the processes related to drought stress were also compromised in plants undergoing pathogen infection. The mutant plant of the aforementioned gene, NDR1, was an excellent model to study this problem.

 

At a molecular-genetic level (i.e., the primary basis for the inheritance for traits), we demonstrated that plants must maintain their fluid levels during infection. At the same time, as a function of a pathogen's need to gain access to nutrients, they must disrupt this balance. In some instances, this might also include, as our research uncovered, "tricking" the plant into believing it was in an environment of restricted water; thus, the plant "decides" that rather than maintain its pathogen-defenses, it can shut those down and redirect energy to prevent itself from undergoing damage as a result of drought.

 

Our research showed, and has become the basis for extending this work into important food crops such as bean and soybean, that plants utlitize similar processes to combat pathogens and stress related to the environment. This work is providing a foundation for us to, one day, develop food crops, through both breeding and genetic modification, that can withstand both, simultaneously.
